Pre-Game Insights: Mabedi said: “The odds are stacked against us, but tomorrow [today] being a special day [Mother’s Day], we need to get a good result to make Malawians happy. We have let them down big time and we owe them a lot. We need to do well and make them happy.”

Mabedi said: “Look, as a coach you can be fired or you can leave any time depending on the situation. So, I am not moved, I am not worried because I know why we find ourselves in such a situation. And unless we correct that, we will continue to struggle even if another coach comes.”
Miscellaneous Highlights: Senegal’s Mane (C) is kept in check by Flames’ Wisdom Mpinganjira (R) and Nickson Mwase

Former Liverpool forward Mane, who now plays for Saudi Arabia top-flight side Al Nassr, will lead the West Africans’ attack line with the hope of increasing his national team goal tally which is now at 45.
Senegal coach Pape Thiaw was quoted by senenews.com as having said they will go flat out to win with more goals so as to catch up with table-toppers Burkina Faso.
Munthali is ineligible for this afternoon’s tie and his absence has opened the door for George Chikooka, who conceded all the four goals in Dakar.
Mabedi said: “What cost us more was the red card. It changed the complexion of the game.”
Others: Burkina Faso’s Stallions punched their ticket to Morocco on Sunday following their 2-0 win over Burundi’s Swallows.
Senegal are second with seven points while Burundi remain third with three points earned in their 3-2 victory over the Flames.
Malawi are fighting for their first point,
Senegal will, therefore, be out to seal the other slot and also keep the Stallions on their toes in the chase for the top spot finish.
